explanation:
For checking the MISRA rule (memcmp must not be used to compare null-terminated strings) you must inspect any called code that obtains or compares textual usernames and any code that compares digests/binary buffers. Brief reasons: 
- MHD_digest_auth_get_username3: returns the username info used by handle_sec_areas_req; must inspect how the username is represented (pointer, length, null-termination) and whether memcmp is ever used on it.
- MHD_get_rq_dauth_params_, get_rq_uname_type, get_rq_unames_size, get_rq_uname: helpers used by MHD_digest_auth_get_username3 to parse the request username; needed to determine whether the extracted username is NUL-terminated or a length-buffer (which affects whether memcmp use would be a violation).
- struct MHD_DigestAuthUsernameInfo: definition shows how username/algo/length are stored; necessary to know if username is a C-string or length-delimited buffer.
- find_entry_by_userinfo: called with username_info to locate the user entry; must inspect its implementation to see if it compares usernames using memcmp (potential MISRA violation) or uses string-safe functions.
- find_entry_by_username and find_entry_by_userhash: callees of find_entry_by_userinfo; required to see the exact comparison routine used (memcmp vs strcmp/strncmp and whether applied to NUL-terminated strings).
- struct UserEntry: contains the stored username and digests; needed to know the type/representation of username and digest fields (char* vs fixed byte arrays) to decide whether comparisons are on strings or binary blobs.
- MHD_digest_auth_check_digest3, digest_auth_check_all, digest_get_hash_size: these perform digest comparisons; include them to verify that memcmp is only used on binary digest buffers (permitted) and not on NUL-terminated username strings.

Inspecting these symbols will let the next analyst determine whether any memcmp usage in the call chain compares null-terminated strings (a MISRA violation) or only fixed-size/binary buffers (acceptable).
